TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Following the untimely death of former Senator Panizza, it was necessary for the government to appoint a new whip, and the government has appointed Senator Paul Calvert as its whip. He was previously deputy whip. The government has also appointed Senator Bill Heffernan as deputy whip.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I congratulate Senator Calvert and Senator Heffernan on their appointments. I do not believe that the Leader of the Government in the Senate has formally informed the Senate that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services has resigned. I was wondering whether he could indicate when he intended to do that.
—When I am ready to make a statement I will.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. The minister has indicated sotto voce and not on his feet that when he is ready to make a statement he will. It is the normal courtesy to inform the Senate chamber immediately a resignation has taken place. That has been Senator Hill's practice when other colleagues, such as Senator Gibson and Senator Short, have resigned their positions. I say very simply: the minister's response is totally unsatisfactory.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, can you confirm that low income families who receive high rates of additional parenting allowance will not be eligible for part B of the family tax initiative even if the spouse is at home caring for children under five? Is it true that this means around 140,000 low income families will be denied $9.60 a week—help they desperately need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad the senator has recognised that Australian families do desperately need help. It was something which yesterday in question time I tried to make very clear: that during 13 years of Labor Australia's families have sunk further and further. Therefore, desperation at the way in which they had been treated caused many previously Labor voting families to vote for the coalition at the last election. But not only were they disenchanted with the previous government; they also recognised that the family tax initiative being promised by the coalition would go some way towards supporting them after all those years of neglect and all that harm to them. We have cut-out points for family income—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The senator is having difficulty hearing because of the interjections from her own side. Some opposition senators clearly do not want to hear the answer. This is a means tested payment to families with a parent at home. We have been very concerned to see that this payment is focused, and that has been widely recognised and welcomed by many community groups, who see the need to support families with a parent at home and basically only one income. That is why the program has been designed in the way that it has.

ANSWER.PARA: Some families will get their benefit through the tax system at the end of the financial year, but something like 900,000 families will get it through the social security system. Many families, even if they do not receive a part B entitlement, will receive a part A entitlement, which is a good deal more than what they got under the previous government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I take it that you are saying yes, 140,000 low income families will be denied the $9.60 a week. If you are trying to encourage women to stay at home and look after the children, why are you punishing so many of them by denying them the full benefit of the family tax initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again obviously the opposition has finally come to the conclusion that they cannot go on knocking the family tax initiative and that they have to recognise it is desirable and useful. However, I dispute very strongly the suggestion which was implied in the supplementary question that the government is in any way trying to send women home. The whole purpose of assistance for families is to recognise that families want to make choices. At different stages of their lives they all want different outcomes. Many families who have an under five in the family want one parent to be able to stay at home. Those who choose differently are also assisted through the tax system by way of two tax thresholds.

ANSWER.PARA: This government is about choice for women and supporting families. We are proud of it, and no matter how much cackle comes from the opposition it is one of the reasons that this government was elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and it concerns Australia's young people. Minister, youth unemployment under the previous Labor government reached an all-time high of 34.8 per cent. Will you inform the Senate of the initiatives the Howard government is taking in relation to enhancing job opportunities for Australia's youth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am very pleased to do so because the Howard coalition government is facing up to the legacy of Labor in this vitally important area. You are right, Senator Coonan; in fact it was June 1992 that youth unemployment reached a record high of 34.8 per cent under Labor. Labor's record: 34.8 per cent youth unemployment. Who was the employment minister at the time? None other than Mr Beazley. Mr Beazley, now Leader of the Opposition, was employment minister of this country when youth unemployment reached 34.8 per cent, Labor's record; 131,700 young people out of work, Labor's record; the highest level of youth unemployment since the Great Depression, Labor's record. As the Howard government tackles the task it inherited from Labor—that of mass unemployment of young Austral ians—let it never be forgotten that what it is tackling is Labor's legacy: mass unemployment of young Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, we do not apologise for the fact that we are going to try some new ideas, because Labor failed. We had 13 years of Labor's ideas and they left mass unemployment of young Australians. So we will try new ideas. We will try the work for the dole idea—an idea that is going to give some young Australians hope; a chance that will give them meaningful work experience; a chance to assist some to break out of the cycle of unproductive activity and isolation that some are experiencing. We do not apologise for that. We are confident it will work and it is good that there is a government that is prepared to try to implement some new ideas to tackle this ingrained unemployment that we have inherited from Labor.

But it is not just that scheme. In just 10 months of government what do we have? We have $200 million to be invested over four years in the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system. We are rejigging the apprenticeship system of this country to give young Australians a better chance of adequate training and a better chance of a job. New traineeships in five key rural industries for up to 1,000 young Australians will begin next month. That is good news for young Australians that were left unemployed by Labor.

We have $41.6 million over three years in the green corps, a good initiative by the Howard government—knocked by Labor, of course, but all they can do these days is just knock; they have no new ideas. That will give 3,500 young Australians experience in the field, environmental experience and work experience. Surprise, surprise, young Australians in their thousands are applying to be part of that scheme. Labor was not interested in it, but thousands of young Australians say they want to be part of it, which demonstrates what young Australians think of Labor.

Remember, Madam President, that there are the new measures to assist schools to better prepare young people for the work force. We have the national schools early literacy strategy, because we recognise that failing to gain literacy skills at an early age puts young people at a disadvantage for all their working life. The Howard government is tackling it. The jobs pathways guarantee will take young people from year 12 directly into jobs and give them a better chance therefore to be able to build a career that is worth while and to give them hope. Four thousand scholarships will be given to the disadvantaged—I could go on for half an hour. This is good news for young Australians; something that they did not get from Labor. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the concerns expressed by the Acting Privacy Commissioner that private health funds are obtaining access to patients' health records in order to verify claims without their permission? Is the minister aware that Medibank Private enjoys this contractual right to access medical records and that it does not require the patient's consent? Should not privately insured patients enjoy the same privacy protection as those in the public sector—that is that the personal consent of the patient or a court order is required prior to access to medical records being provided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter in which there is already an inquiry. It is also a matter on which we have rarely, if ever, heard the opposition speak. Somehow privacy is something that they have suddenly discovered after nearly a year of opposition and 13 years in government. I will get an answer from the minister responsible, Dr Wooldridge.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, while you are seeking that information on a matter that has been on the public record for almost a month now, could you also give an undertaking that you will urge the minister for health to actually take some action in this regard and require the consent of patients to be obtained before access is given to their records?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I will draw the supplementary question to the minister's notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Got it in one, Senator Collins. My question refers to the Hindmarsh Island Bridge fiasco created by Labor. Will the minister provide details of the costs to the Australian taxpayer to date associated with the Hindmarsh Island Bridge saga? Will the minister outline further costs and any other ramifications of the Labor Party and Australian Democrats' rejection of the Hindmarsh Island bill which would have brought this sorry saga to an end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman. As a South Australian, Senator Chapman, you stood up for South Australians, which cannot be said about opposition South Australian senators. They have to respond to the South Australian electors for this fiasco. At least the Labor Party people are consistent: they produced the fiasco and now they are continuing the fiasco.

ANSWER.PARA: You would think that, after 13 years, they would have learned something, but they have not. It was the big nail in the political coffin of the Labor Party at the last election, and the lid is still slammed down and the nail is still there. They are not going to climb out of this because I am going to have much pleasure reminding the Australian taxpayers about this right up until the next election. That fiasco that they created has produced a cost to the Australian taxpayers of over $4 million. I understand the cost to the South Australian government for an inquiry and a royal commission amounted to $2.2 million. Those on that side produced that cost.

The cost to the Commonwealth for the Saunders and Mathews inquiries was over a million dollars. On top of that, the Commonwealth has spent an estimated $1.15 million in associated legal costs. That is over $4 million. Will you go to the next election and say to the Australian public that you have forced us to spend more money? You created the mess and we are trying to clear it up, but you will not let us do it.

BREAK.PARA: The Saunders inquiry, which was the only inquiry that found against the construction of the bridge, was overturned on appeal. The Mathews inquiry was found to be unconstitutional.
Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you and your colleagues made a monumental blunder when you appointed a serving judge to make an inquiry. You did not have the wit to know the difference between appointing a serving judge and the executive.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not speak, Senator Bolkus. You voted yesterday as a South Australian. Go and explain that to the South Australian public. We sought all manner of advice, but the legislation was defeated by the Democrats themselves. Who is going to pick up the bill? My portfolio. ATSIC are going to pick up the bill of another inquiry.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep this up, Senator Ray. I thought you had more brains than the rest of them put together, but it is obvious that even you cannot understand it. I feel sorry for those on that side. The spurious argument raised was that it was against the Racial Discrimination Act. Our general counsel said, `No, the bill, in my opinion, as I previously advised, is not inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act.' That was our general counsel.

BREAK.PARA: There was a suggestion that a short and dirty inquiry could produce something. Even their main adviser on that side said that it would be a sham. The Mathews inquiry cost over a million dollars. It will cost at least half a million dollars to get a decent inquiry going.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was $1 million yesterday.

—It may cost more than a million, Senator Collins. Thank you for coming in on that. It may cost more than a million. You have to get something that is ironclad on this, Senator Collins. I would hope that those on the other side realise that you cannot have a short and dirty inquiry. You have to have a due process inquiry. With all the various inquiries, the legal costs and everything else that has been going on, it would not surprise me that the bridge could have been built by now. All that time and energy—(Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister was referring to how this money may have been better spent than on various legal inquiries and advice. Would the minister like to further advise the Senate as to a better way in which this money could have been spent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman for the supplementary question because that goes to the nub of it. This money could be spent on Aboriginal housing, health and education. This is money that is being diverted from the ATSIC portfolio. The Democrats, Senator Kernot in particular, were unaware of that. Senator Margetts, who unfortunately is not here, was also unaware of that when she asked where the money was coming from. The answer is that it comes from the taxpayers via the ATSIC budget, because under the ATSIC Act they are responsible for the payment of the inquiries.
—You have cut the budget by $400 million.

—All this humbug is going on about the cuts to the ATSIC budget when here is almost another million dollars going out of that budget, Senator Kernot. I will remind the Australian public about your involvement in it. I will remind them continually that you were unaware that this was so. I thank Senator Chapman for his question. I could elaborate further on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, it is up to you to go to the South Australian taxpayers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, why is it that you, as the employment minister, have been cut out of the only employment related initiative that your government has been able to come up with and the job has been given to your junior minister? Was it that you, unlike the Prime Minister, were clever enough to realise that during the federal election campaign the Liberal Party responded to an election questionnaire by stating, `We do not support the introduction of a work for the dole scheme.' Of course, Mr Howard has just explained to the House of Representatives that it was not really his answer; it was just prepared in the Liberal Party secretariat. Is it the case that our forgetful Prime Minister has just lost complete confidence in you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, the answer to your last question is absolutely not. The answer to the earlier part of your question is that the government will decide who has which jobs without consulting you. This may be a surprise to you but, as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, you do not actually get much say over who has which jobs. You could argue a variety of places that a work for the dole scheme might go. You might say that social security should look after it. After discussions with the Prime Minister, it was decided that the appropriate portfolio is that of employment, education, training and youth affairs. Dr Kemp is well capable of taking on this task, and I am sure he will do it very well. Frankly, I do not understand any concern you might have with his having that job.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The problem for Senator Vanstone is that the question of who has which job is apparently a matter for the Prime Minister, but he has been determining it without consulting her. I ask the minister—

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I think he is finally going to ask a question, but I was going to invite you to remind him that that was what he was on his feet to do, not to make a statement. He can have a debate after question time if he wants to do so, but when he rises on a supplementary question he should ask the question.
—Order! Do you have anything further to say, Senator Faulkner?

—I was planning on completing my supplementary question, thank you, Madam President. Minister, can you tell the Senate what reasons the Prime Minister gave for dumping you, when informing you that Dr Kemp would be given ministerial responsibility for the work for the dole scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes, Senator Faulkner, you are cute; today is not one of them. I am not in the practice of going to the Prime Minister and saying, `Look, I think you owe me an explanation as to why you've done this, this or this.' That is just crazy. I had a discussion with him about where the appropriate responsibility should lie and agreed that it should lie in this portfolio. After that, if you have any questions, why don't you go and ask him yourself?

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, the ship Kilauea is now moving away from Magnetic Island due to the threat posed by tropical Cyclone Gillian. It has not refuelled. I ask the minister: was the United States Navy's order for a million litres of fuel and their request for safety backup during the refuelling at sea operation a planned or unplanned exercise? Now that the Kilauea is moving away to an unknown destination, are they still planning to refuel over the reef, and have all the pollution control vessels and equipment gone with them? Can you confirm that during the unloading of live ammunition, a carton of 50 smoke grenades was lost overboard and that Navy divers were sent down to recover them? And, based on the safety guarantees that you gave this chamber yesterday, can you assure us that all material lost overboard—either that which has already been lost or anything that is lost during Operation Tandem Thrust—will be recovered and accounted for?
—As the ship is moving away, I presume the honourable senator now accepts that it had not run out of fuel.
—It was being rowed!

—Yesterday it was drifting around without fuel, apparently! In actual fact, I understand that where it was to have been refuelled was not within the park at all. But I am told that, because of deteriorating weather conditions, the refuelling operation has been cancelled. The arrangements for the refuelling operation were agreed by the two relevant planning and management authorities—that is, GBRMPA and the Townsville Port Authority. It was to have occurred within the boundaries of the port and not the marine park. I am not sure where it will refuel in the future. I will see whether we have been told of the future intentions of the military in relation to the refuelling of that vessel. And, yes, I understand that there has been—
—Can't you do any better than this?

—I think I am doing pretty well, actually. I understand that there was an inadvertent drop of some smoke grenades, which was rather unfortunate, I would have thought. Two grenades were recovered immediately by boat; the remainder sank in 10 metres of water. Australian Navy clearance divers were immediately despatched to recover the remaining grenades and commenced their search at first light on Tuesday. I am further informed that the diving team failed to locate any of the remaining grenades, and their search was suspended after five hours. The likelihood of search success is low. I understand that it is not believed that there is any danger to the civilian population that might follow from this accident.

—I am not quite sure where to start with a supplementary question as there are so many of them. Perhaps I can just ask: Minister, who will be paying for the exercise? The United States Navy requested that our pollution control, both experts and equipment—according to this media release from GBRMPA—be sent out to help them. Will we be paying for their mistakes? Most importantly, Minister, can you give us a full guarantee that there will be no further incidents during Operation Tandem Thrust? If you cannot give us such a guarantee, how can you fulfil your responsibilities under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the World Heritage Act to protect the area from activities `likely to damage or destroy'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure which mistake she is now alleging.
—Any one of your many.

—There has been no mistake in relation to the refuelling. It was decided that this vessel would be refuelled. It was brought in close to shore into the port area to be refuelled. Because of deteriorating weather conditions, it was decided not to refuel the vessel. So where is the mistake in that?

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the loss of the smoke grenades, I would like to give my personal guarantee that such an incident will not recur, but I obviously cannot. However, what I can tell you is that we have great confidence that, in preparation for this important defence exercise—and, of course, the other half of the story is that you do not like the idea of a defence exercise, but we believe it is in Australia's best interests—there has been a lot of care taken to ensure that it can be done both environmentally responsibly and responsibly in other ways as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Minister, is it a fact that the Minister for Defence has admitted that the defence budget will not rise in line with the CPI? Is it not the case that this represents well over a $100 million cut in real terms? How do you reconcile this with your election commitment that `there will be no cuts in defence spending from the existing forward estimates'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the minister having made any such statement. I will certainly check with him as to whether there is such a statement. Nevertheless, I would point out that this question certainly comes pretty hollowly from the other side of the chamber after all the 13 years that we watched protesting while the Labor Party cut further and further into Australia's defence. The manpower levels and the funding levels have gone down and down to some of the lowest commitments that Australia has made since the Second World War.

BREAK.PARA: So in every real sense the Labor Party is in no moral position to say anything about the future of defence funding. At a time when this government inherited more than $10 billion of debt in the national accounts from the outgoing Labor government, the one portfolio which was protected was defence. It was protected because it was recognition of the treatment by the previous government of the defence of Australia. It ill-behoves the Labor Party to quibble in the least about the way this government is spending the defence dollar, because this government is doing it prudently and with every concern for efficiency. Mr McLachlan has instituted a major efficiency review of the Department of Defence, which should have been done by the outgoing minister before he left. He knows full well that in a budget of $10 billion there is always room for improvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer Senator Kemp to the decision of the government to abolish the general independent Austudy rate and to deem those students to be dependent upon their parents. Is it not a fact that the income tax initiative that the government was so proud of—and, in many cases, justifiably—actually deems those very selfsame students as being not dependent upon the parents? What are you going to do to remedy that inconsistency in the next budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question about Austudy, of course, that relates to another portfolio. In relation to the matter of the family income tax initiative, I will take that question on notice, and I will get back to the chamber on that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the minister confirm claims made by the member for Herbert that single women are having children just to make a profit from the welfare system? In particular, has the minister's attention been drawn to Mr Lindsay's claim that he is aware of women who have said, `Oh, we need more money to pay the car off. Let's have another kid'? Can the minister confirm that Mr Lindsay is now to join the government's backbench committee that formulates government policy on child support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation of sole parents in this country is that they are some of the most disadvantaged and poor people in the nation. While it is a fairly widely held view that women and girls are having babies in order to achieve more income from the social security department, I think it is a cruel slur on most women who are trying to raise children on their own. From memory I would point out that something like three per cent of sole parents are teenagers, and this criticism is usually directed at teenagers.

ANSWER.PARA: Most of the mothers on sole parents benefit have between one and three children. I think the average is about two. They are usually either widows or divorcees or deserted wives in the old nomenclature. They are having a hard job of it, which is why John Howard's government was so determined that a one-income family—as a sole parent family is—could get proper protection and additional support from the family tax initiative.

That is exactly what has happened. The National Council for the Single Mother and her Child—which I mentioned yesterday, but you were shouting so loudly that you did not hear—welcomed that initiative because of what it meant for sole parent families in particular and low income families in general.

So I do not endorse any attempt to criticise sole parent families who are doing it tough. Anybody who has tried to raise children on their own would regard that as being one of life's most difficult jobs. The few cases that individuals may know of where rorting is going on should be brought to the attention of the Department of Social Security.

Anybody on a social security pension who has a baby over nine months after going on to the pension is automatically reviewed for entitlement to the pension. If it is found that such people are, in fact, living as part of a couple in a marriage-like relationship, they lose the entitlement. If members of the community know of situations where the revenue is being defrauded, I would ask them to draw the attention of the department to it so that the matter can be properly investigated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I did not hear your answer to the question about whether you knew of Mr Lindsay's statement. Could you please answer that question and also tell us what you intend to do as a consequence of that statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to Mr Lindsay's statement and I have in fact just made a very clear statement in this chamber in the last minute or so. I would hope that the honourable senator would accept that that is a fairly clear statement of a government's position on sole parents and entitlement to benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not answer the part that went to Mr Lindsay's involvement in child support measures. I would suppose that more than 50 per cent of members of parliament are concerned about the child support arrangements in this country which were started by the previous government with the support of our opposition parties. However, I do not think anybody would believe that it is working as well as it should and there are many unfairnesses in the system.

ANSWER.PARA: The previous government did not in fact move to implement the recommendations of the inquiry and so when we came into government it was left to us to attend to. We are now working on implementation of those reforms and Mr Lindsay, like many other members of the coalition, is working with the government to achieve reform. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Given that small business growth remains the key to reducing unemployment and given the coalition's support for small business by giving capital gains tax relief, removing Labor's unfair dismissal laws and passing the pro‐business industrial relations laws, will the prospects for the unemployed be further helped if business, including small business, enjoys low interest rates on their loans? Can the minister report on any recent favourable developments in business lending rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for that question. His concern for people in small business and the unemployed is well known in this chamber. Of course he is right that the key focus of the government's attention is for the government to do all it can to help small business and help small business provide jobs through low interest rates, low inflation and high investment.

ANSWER.PARA: We have delivered the CGT relief, reduced provisional tax—which has been of great benefit to small business—reduced the paperwork burden on small business and generally provided an appropriate environment for the growth of jobs.

Business has already benefited from lower interest rates. Rates for small business have gone down the full amount of cuts in official rates. Average rates have fallen from 11¼ per cent when Labor was thrown out of government down to 9.75 per cent today. For a small business with a loan of some $500,000, this provides an interest benefit—a reduction of $7,500 a year or about $140 a week. This clearly is a major boost to small business and helps in our aim of creating the right environment to create jobs.

The government strongly welcomes signs of increased business loan competition. We have all seen and indeed welcome the big benefits that home owners have enjoyed from strong competition in the home lending market. Aussie Home Loans, the biggest non‐bank lender, has just entered the business loan market and many senators would have seen the news last night. It claims that this move will help revolutionise small business lending. They have announced that they will be offering business loans at the standard variable rate of 7.49 per cent, which is, I understand, 2¼ percentage points below the average rate of the big four banks. Again, this will translate through to very, very big savings for small business.

The government welcomes this competition which can only be good news for business and workers and calls on and certainly hopes that the banks will respond to this competition. In fact, I would urge all borrowers, whether they be home buyers, credit card holders or small businesses, to shop around to ensure that they get the best deal. Labor failed to provide a low interest rate climate. The only thing that Labor is good at is branch stacking, but in terms of creating real jobs, Labor failed.
Senator Gibbs interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the senator knows the interest rate levels that loans to small businesses reached when her party was in government. I wonder if you do know. I suspect the answer is that you do not. I can advise you that your policies—Labor's high interest rate policies—saw the interest rates available to small business peaking at well over 20 per cent. That was the result of the policies that your government brought in. In response to that—(Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask supplementary question. Can Senator Kemp compare those high interest rate policies with those prevailing today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson again. With the very high interest rate policies that Labor imposed on the community and particularly on small business, it is no wonder that small business struggled under Labor. Labor made no apology for these very high interest rates, no apology at all. PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the government to accept that: "Respect for the democratic principles and basic human rights, as proclaimed in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, underpins the internal and international policies of . . . Australia" and to agree to the inclusion of that form of words in any trade agreement with the European Community.

I must say I am surprised that the terms of this urgency motion have come to the attention of the Australian public in general, the European public in general and especially this parliament. The fact that Australia is not prepared to sign a treaty—whether it be about trade, human rights, hot air balloons landing in Australia, defence, economics or anything at all—with human rights clauses in it is absolutely extraordinary. The people whom I have spoken to in Europe about this—indeed anyone I have spoken to around the world, including Australia—also find it absolutely extraordinary.

The level of a nation's commitment to human rights, whether in domestic practices or in foreign policy, is the litmus test for the quality of its democracy. Respect for human rights cannot be separated from any other aspect of government policy. On 10 December last year, both the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and I addressed the National Press Club on this issue. He stated:

BREAK.PARA: This Government views human rights as an inseparable part of Australia's overall foreign policy approach.
Why then did that minister, in a letter to the Vice President of the European Commission, write:

I have to say that the existence of operative human rights and non-fulfilment provisions as proposed by the Community remains in our view inappropriate in an agreement on trade and co‐operation . . . between Australia and the European Community.
The least you can say about that position is that it is thoroughly inconsistent.

The government's position on this raises some very serious questions about the strength and the sincerity of Australia's declared commitment to indivisible human rights. It also raises questions about whether international trade and human rights can and ought to be totally separate. The Democrats do not think they can, nor should they be. Each and every international treaty that we sign ought to contain a reference to upholding the universal declaration of human rights. That is the absolute building block of the basic rights of every single person who belongs to every single one of the 185 nations that make up the United Nations.

Interestingly, the government's position on the trade treaty is being strongly backed by groups such as the Business Council of Australia, but it is of concern to those organisations whose primary focus is on maintaining basic human rights standards—organisations such as Community Aid Abroad, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, the ACTU and many more.
The trade outcomes and objectives statement of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Fischer) of 5 February this year clearly places Asia at the centre of his strategy. He states that:
. . . we are unique in being a developed country with a strong comparative advantage in the rural and mining industries . . .

I do not think anyone would disagree with that. But if we are at such an advantage in a trade sense, then why not in a human rights capacity as well? One also has to ask, is this furious campaign to engage with Asia in a trade sense actually our trade reality?

The European Union is of great importance to Australia. For example, the European Union is Australia's largest economic partner; larger than Japan when you take into consideration merchandise trade, trade in services, financial transfers and direct foreign investment. I cannot understand the government's position under article 32 of the treaty that gives `any European country the option of walking away from its obligations under the agreement on the basis of undefined human rights criteria'. Those human rights criteria are very well spelt out. They are human rights criteria contained within the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights. As Nobel Peace Prize laureate Jose Ramos Horta stated recently, `Human rights are not a Western concept; they are a human concept.'

Let us look at the two articles in the proposed European Union framework to which Australia objects. They are article 1, which declares respect for universal human rights as an essential element of the agreement—and I cannot see a problem with that—and article 32, which allows either party to withdraw from the agreement after lengthy and complicated examination, consultation and negotiation.

Article 32 is referred to as the non-fulfilment clause. It allows either party to withdraw from the treaty in instances where the other party has failed to fulfil an obligation under the agreement. As I have just said, withdrawal is not automatic. Except in circumstances of special urgency, the parties seeking to withdraw from the agreement must supply the other with all relevant information required for a thorough examination of the situation with a view to seeking a solution which is acceptable to both parties. After all—and this makes complete sense—maintenance of the treaty is the paramount consideration.

So what could possibly be the problem? If the government is concerned about the way in which Australia adheres to its international and domestic human rights obligations, then they ought to fix the matter about which they are concerned. But that does not seem to be such an easy proposition. The Deputy Prime Minister has made no secret of the way in which he, as trade minister, feels about human rights. He has indicated that Australia would not allow any reservations over China's human rights record to influence this government's attitude to trade with that country. He has said, `We do not have the capacity of being the world's policing authority or the world's conscience on human rights.' What a very offensive thing to say, but he has said it.

But he did not stop there. He has played down China's brutal occupation of Tibet, and he has rejected trade sanctions against Burma over its appalling human rights record. Based on this record alone, why should the Australian community place any importance in the government upholding human rights in their trade partnerships?

The European trade treaty human rights clause is not the only human rights forum in which the government is seeking to wind back Australia's involvement. Since coming into government, the coalition has been very keen to distance Australia from international forums. We are disturbed by this transition. We believe we must never accept the idea that the internationalisation of the economy forces us to accept lower industrial standards. On the contrary, the internationalisation of the economy is the strongest argument for the internationalisation of labour rights and industrial standards.

We have a sound reputation in that area. Australia was a foundation member of the International Labour Organisation nearly 80 years ago. We have made a contribution to the ILO which is well in excess of our size as an economic power. We have developed a strong reputation as a defender of human rights and labour rights throughout the world. And an essential element of our ability to raise questions about human rights in other countries is our credibility. As the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, said on 6 February this year, `Australia's commitment to human rights is unequivocal and our record is second to none.' I certainly hope that is still the case.

But we cannot rest there. We must continue to practise what we preach. Australia cannot allow an ideological perspective on the value of the ILO, for instance, to cloud the import ance of ratifying treaties and conventions which exist to protect the human rights of our overseas counterparts as well as our own population. In the words of Gough Whitlam:
. . . State indifference or intransigence are no longer excuses for our national failure to meet our international obligations.
How true.

A trend is emerging of international withdrawal and irresponsibility within this government and, indeed, around the world. At all times this government should be seeking to meet the grade of international best practice in absolutely everything that we do. We cannot expect to even come close by not signing the human rights clause in the EU trade treaty. If we are to remain a respected player in international human rights forums, we have to practise what we preach. The Prime Minister is right when he said that. But neither he nor his cabinet ministers are acting in accordance with that commitment to anywhere near the extent that we would like to see.

Withdrawal from the ILO is merely one United Nations forum from which this government has retreated. Australia has reduced its expenditure on UNICEF, the world population fund, UNDP, UNRWA, UNEP, the Global Environment Facility and the Montreal Protocol Multilateral Fund, and the reproductive health program in the WHO. Contributions to the UNHCR, the International Red Cross and emergency aid have also been reduced. The government also has announced its withdrawal from the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation. It has cut back on grants to a number of community based organisations, including the United Nations Association of Australia. Most of this has been done without consultation. So where is the commitment to human rights in that?

The government maintains that human rights and labour standards are the province of such United Nations organisations. But with withdrawals and cutbacks in funding, including our own, this government can easily wipe its hands of any further need to provide for them in negotiations for trade. That all seems so very tidy.

Let us make no mistake about this. In this so-called new era of globalisation, countries will rely more and more upon international law and agreement to develop common responses to global issues. In that sort of climate, generating a positive public response to treaties becomes increasingly important. We have to convince our fellow Australians that we cannot pull up this drawbridge.

There are many problems in this world today, and they can only be solved by governments cooperating to set national and international standards and international rules. This government is now fighting very hard to ensure that human rights are not linked to trade when, in fact, as we all know, human rights are linked to everything.

What all this adds up to is that Australia is going backwards on basic human rights. I believe that more than a decade's worth of economic rationalism has a lot to do with that, and it has led to the point where we are in danger of instilling in Australians a sense that human rights are not important, that they can and should be downgrade and traded off in pursuit of more important economic goals. If we do not halt that trend, we will never become a tolerant, mature or civilised society, and we will never be able to influence or to improve human rights either here in Australia or anywhere else in the world.

The point is that overall the Australian economy suffers badly because of the level of our current account deficit, which is a level of about four per cent of GDP. The only way we can repair the current account deficit is to become more competitive as a nation and to sell more goods or to replace more imports than we currently do and to add value to primary products that we export out of this nation.

However, there is a positive step that can be taken which will help Australian exporters, and that would be for this country to sign the negotiated European Union trade and cooperation framework agreement. This debate is really about why this government is dillydallying in signing—the sole reason why it refuses to open the door to this agreement and allow the Australian exporters to take a bigger share of the European market and repair some of the current account and adverse trading balance figures that we have with Europe.

The sole reason that this government advances is that the proposal put by the Europeans contains a human rights clause. From our side of politics it is worth asking: is that sufficient reason to block the economic advantages and the jobs for Australians that will flow from them in the case of this agreement? It seems to me and to my party that the answer is: absolutely not. The reason why we conclude that is that, of course, this is more than simply a trade agreement. It is a trade and cooperation framework.

It is not surprising that not just trade matters appear in the agreement—other matters appear in it as well. If this were a straight and narrow trade agreement, one could be rightfully suspicious of the introduction of extraneous clauses. It is broader than that because, in a straight trade agreement, the only reason to put in an extraneous clause is to try to somehow interfere with the trade issues by introducing side matters. That is not the case here. It is a trade and cooperation agreement.

But what does this agreement ask us to do as a nation? It asks us to sign on to the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights as being the determinant of human rights values between the European Union and Australia. That is a very unexceptionable request. Australia is already bound to observe the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights. We are bound because we have signed onto it within the United Nations. If the Europeans invite us to sign onto it between us and them, what is surprising about that? It is a consistency of behaviour because we have affirmed those standards to the world, not just to that regional grouping in Europe. So the request itself is unsurprising.

But the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is saying that we are not going to sign that. He gives us his reason that `any European country can exercise the option of walking away from its obligations under the agreement on the basis of undefined human rights criteria'. That explanation does not wash. It does not wash because it does not stack up when logic is applied to it. Firstly, what does he mean by `undefined human rights criteria'? The United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights is the centrepiece in the world for global human rights standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we're a signatory to that.

—And we are a signatory to it. So what is wrong with signing it twice—at a regional level as well as at a global level? You cannot say, however—as the Prime Minister imputes in his rejection of it—that it contains `undefined human rights criteria'. This is a document under the microscope worldwide, and its criteria are set out therein. It is not `undefined'; there are criteria in the universal declaration itself.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, can countries unilaterally walk away from it? That would be true if article Y were not in the European proposal for signature for Australia. Article Y in the proposed framework agreement is headed `Article Y on non-fulfilment'. That is to say, if a nation does not fulfil its obligations under this agreement, what then occurs? If one reads article Y, which is a very simple article, it says:
If either Party considers that the other Party has failed to fulfil any of its obligations under this Agreement, it may take appropriate measures. Before so doing—
and then it makes an exception about urgency, which is dealt with later and appropriately, I might say—
it shall supply the Association/Cooperation Council with all relevant information required for a thorough examination of the situation with a view to seeking a solution acceptable to the Parties.

So if there were an objection about Australia's human rights record by a European, they are required to enter into a process to say what that objection is, to have the matter investigated and examined, to participate in a procedure which would bring about a resolution between the two nations—or the two groups of nations in the case of Europe and Australia—and to try to work at solving the matter.

The extraordinary defensiveness of the Prime Minister's position is alarming. It may be that he fears that there are some human rights infractions in Australia that Europeans might object to. If there are, let them say so, and let us have the debate out. This is an important consideration here, because this human rights clause is a two-way street. It is not just for Europeans to operate on Australia but it is, as well, for Australians to operate on Europe. If people have been to Europe and seen the treatment of minorities—of Arabs in France, of Africans in France and Germany, of gipsies everywhere and of eastern Europeans, where poverty is striking people in the former Soviet Union, who are coming across and trying to find jobs in the more developed and affluent West—they would have seen the prospect of considerable concern about human rights. They are prospects and concerns that Europeans themselves raise.

We only have to watch on our television screens the scenes of neo‐Nazi mobs in Germany last year burning down buildings because of protests they were conducting to raise again substantial questions on the European side about human rights. In this case, if there was a major infraction in Europe would Australia sit on its hands? It has an avenue under this agreement to raise those questions and they are important options for us too. It is not—and this is a very relevant consideration—a one‐way street; it is a two‐way street that we can operate.

Finally, one always needs to be careful in international agreements about whether they can be capriciously used. As someone who has negotiated on behalf of this nation on matters of trade with the Europeans, I know that one has to be very careful in their case. I know that some of the stories that circulate in France about Australian agriculture are totally unrepresentative. I would say too that some of the actions of French legislators about Australia in order to try to prevent Australian goods which are competitive entering their market are without conscience and totally unfair practices.

The prospect of a nation misbehaving itself or the possibility of that is something to be guarded against. However, the question is: do you guard against it by simply refusing to be part of an agreement which opens the door to further trade opportunities? This is with not just one nation, but with a group of nations—the whole of the European Union. If there is one nation, they need to get their complaint up, registered and accepted by the rest of them before they proceed.

I think there are sufficient safeguards here so that Australia can say that as a nation in the world our proud record on human rights can be exemplified in this agreement if we sign it. In the past we have been a nation—and I hope we can continue to be in the future—that goes around the world telling other countries when we think that they have broken human rights standards. We told the Chinese when they put that Australian businessman in gaol and we criticised them about Tiananmen Square. We raised questions about East Timor. We put our nose in on human rights unapologetically everywhere. It would be a massive hypocrisy if we did not allow ourselves to be open to the same sort of scrutiny. (Time expired)

But frankly, we feel that the possibility of that happening is so remote that it's a little unconscionable that this should stick out as a sore thumb because it doesn't do, I think, Australia any good at all because a lot of people are saying, `Australia! Human rights! Got a problem!' and not understanding really that there is no problem about human rights between us.

I find it very difficult to believe that, if countries as diverse as Korea, Chile, Armenia, Israel, Tunisia, Vietnam, Georgia, Slovenia, and a number of other countries, are prepared to sign, Australia would have any realistic excuse, unless the government is planning something it feels may raise the ire of the European Community. On this issue, Noel Pearson said:

If there's nothing in our recent history about which we can feel ashamed, is there something in our prospective history about which we might feel that we are going to enter into a breach of human rights?

Could that be the government ignoring the principles in the Racial Discrimination Act to overturn the High Court's Wik decision on native title and pastoral leases? That is a question that I think the government's action leaves for the Australian people.

As Senator Cook has said, Prime Minister Howard told a senior German minister that this government would not be backing down over human rights and trade because any European country would have the option of walking away from its obligations under the agreement on the basis of undefined human rights criteria.

The European Union has used the human rights clause to punish only two countries—Somalia and Nigeria. Does the Australian government fear that our human rights record is no better than that in Somalia or Nigeria? That is the question the government ought to answer.

I was very proud to hear former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam talk at the Sydney Town Hall last Sunday. He touched on a related matter: the hostility of the Howard government and previous coalition governments towards International Labour Organisation conventions. Members of this coalition government have a pathological hatred of international conventions. That has been demonstrated in this chamber on so many occasions.

Gough Whitlam used the example of the disgraceful downsizing of the Australian delegation to the ILO in June of last year to highlight the Howard government's isolationism. There were no federal and no state ministers as part of that delegation. We are no longer represented on the ILO governing body. Worst of all, the Australian government is no longer supporting ILO programs in Asia.

Senator Bourne gave a long list, including UNICEF, of international organisations that have been cut by this government, showing the government's isolationism and its lack of interest in proper international cooperation. The common pattern in this government is a lack of interest in acting for human rights and industrial rights and a lack of interest in helping other countries raise the quality of their human rights practices.

At the moment, we are at an impasse and Australia is suffering because of it. Our international reputation is suffering and unemployed Australians are being denied jobs, because trade is at the kernel of solving unemployment in the long term. The solution is simple. It is straightforward. Yet the Howard-Fischer government procrastinates. I make the point that it is a coalition government because the National Party members are just as guilty of indecisiveness over this matter.

If you look at the situation we are in at the moment, you see that we have got an $11.4 billion deficit with the EC. That is very serious. Along with the United States deficit, these are perhaps the two biggest areas we need to address with improved trade and cooperation arrangements. Unfortunately, this government has been incapable of being decisive. As it does on so many other things, it has wasted the opportunity before it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues Senator MacGibbon and Senator Sandy Macdonald on this motion of urgency. The government is opposing this motion. Our fundamental problem is the specific linkage between human rights and possible non-fulfilment action in the operative part of the draft agreement. I would like to take issue with the remarks made by Senator Margetts, who indicated that no non-fulfilment action would take place without consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 32 on non-fulfilment allows one party to take appropriate measures and to take such measures without prior consultation in circumstances of special urgency. Together, article 32 and article 31 would enable either party to suspend or terminate the agreement unilaterally without prior consultation. The government's attitude to this treaty is not one of fear or loathing. On the other hand, we are simply not prepared to agree to provisions in a trade agreement which will allow either party unilaterally to undertake the actions that I have just mentioned.

Senator Margetts also said that we do not have a choice. We do have a choice. This is the choice that both the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) have announced—that we find the inclusion of the human rights clause unacceptable in a trade and economic framework. Any issues of trade and cooperation will not be solved by the inclusion of a human rights clause.

If, Senator Bourne, we are distancing ourselves from international forums, why is it that during this year the Italian foreign minister will make his first visit in nine years, the French foreign minister will make his first visit in 13 years, the German economics minister will make his first visit in nine years, the Dutch Prime Minister will make his first visit and we will have the first visit by a German head of government for nine years? None of this is distancing us from international forums.

How many other countries have agreed to human rights provisions in their agreements with the European Community? Only around nine of the European Community's agreements with other countries include both human rights and associated non-fulfilment provisions as proposed for the agreement with Australia. That alone should sound warning bells. No other OECD country except South Korea has agreed to sign a comparable agreement containing these clauses. Many of the other types of agreement entered into are different types of agreement not comparable to the text we have under discussion.

Senator Childs indicated the long list of non-compliance with human rights clauses instanced by Senator Bourne. Unfortunately, I do not have time to read out the equally long list that I have of the government's recent action on human rights. But I can assure you that none of them indicate our pathological hatred of international institutions. On the contrary, all of them indicate our willingness to be involved at this level, but there is equal caution over why we should not be involved in international treaties or framework agreements without carefully studying them first and making sure that they work to the benefit of Australia and not to its disadvantage in international forums.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not got a copy of the proposed agreement. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee does not insist upon its amendments Nos 16 to 18, 20, 22, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31, 32, 34 and 36 disagreed to by the House of Representatives.

The government has a very real concern in relation to all these measures because the mandate the government received at the last election has not been observed by the Senate. There is no doubt that during the election in February the then opposition made it very clear that it would proceed to provide legislation for a waiting period of two years in terms of welfare benefits for newly arrived migrants. We did not specify social security benefits. In fact, it has been our intention to move to other measures outside the social security portfolio. We were quite clear about the need to do this. The government has not attempted to mislead the electorate. We have honoured our commitment, and the government believes it should be entitled to have that mandate put into effect.

In terms of the items in the amendments we are dealing with together, I do not know quite how senators would like to handle the specifics—whether they want to debate issues involving the carer pension, the widow allowance, the disability wage supplement, the newstart allowance in the treatment of members of certain couples, the mature age allowance, et cetera.
