SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me perhaps make a short contribution.
—That will be the only good thing about it.

—Well, Senator, you have talked me into it—I think a long contribution is in order. In fact, two or three long contributions may well be called for. So I thank you for that interjection. I think you might regret that statement.
—You will regret it more: we are on broadcast.
—Order on my right!

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I appreciate your protection. For the purposes of making what I hope is a brief contribution in the same spirit as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) suggested she might approach this yesterday, I will make a comment that applies to amendments 16, 17, 18, 22, 25, 26, 28, 31, 32, and 36 and then perhaps comment very briefly on the other questions before the chair. I think that would be a sensible way of dealing with these issues, which I know senators in the chamber are well apprised of because we have debated this matter at great length.

SPEECH.PARA: This Senate has allowed this government to make new migrants wait two years before they can claim newstart, sickness or youth training allowance. This Senate has held this government to its election commitment. That really allows the government to keep most of the projected savings in relation to these measures. The only reason that the government is not already accruing savings from these measures is that it saw fit not to return the amended legislation to this chamber last year. I would be the first to concede that the savings would be a little less, but there still would have been quite substantial savings.

The government is on work experience, frankly, in relation to the way this place works. The fact of the matter is that it has been losing the much vaunted savings that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) had spoken about at such great length and it has been losing savings from the part of the measure that has in fact been improved by the Senate.

But of course the Senate has not allowed the extension of the two-year waiting period to a range of payments beyond those which were canvassed by the government during the election campaign. So the Senate has not allowed a two-year waiting period on the higher rate of family payment, on maternity allowance, on health care cards and on a range of other payments. It has done no more or no less than to say to this government, `We require you to honour the commitment you made to the Australian people.' In other words, the government said that a range of payments would be subject to the extension of the waiting period from six months to two years, and those other payments have not been accepted by the Senate.

So the Senate has not allowed the opportunity for the coalition to create a situation where new migrants who work and pay taxes are treated as second‐class citizens—not eligible for the payments available to other low income families such as the higher rates of family payment or rent assistance. The Senate has said to this coalition government, `We will not allow you to withdraw the social safety net from those people.' That was a perfectly reasonable position for us to have taken. For the Senate to say, `You are required to honour your political commitments; you are required to keep your word to the Australian people,' is not unreasonable. We do not resile from arguing that case strongly before this chamber.

The other amendments before us—Nos 20, 23 and 34, so very well described by you, Mr Chairman, as category B amendments, which ought to confuse a lot of people as they ponder the difference between them—are basically omissions to restore exemption from the waiting period where a partner has already been in Australia for six months. In relation to those three amendments the opposition's position remains the same. Our opposition of course to these items effectively restores the exemption and I will be commending to this chamber this evening our continued strong support for this position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats' position in relation to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill and these changes has not changed. Many of the amendments—numbered 16 through to about 33—we are dealing with largely reflect the amendments that I moved during the debate last year on the social security bill. The Democrats made clear then, as I hope to do now, our opposition to the intent behind that bill. We found quite mean spirited the move by the government to extend in some cases a two-year waiting period for benefits that already had a waiting period, but we were also quite angry at the attempt to apply a two-year waiting period to a raft of social security benefits and measures that had previously not had a waiting period.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Faulkner's point is particularly important: this cuts to the heart of the issue as to how we view and treat migrants in our community. I make very clear to people—and this was not so clear in previous debates on this and other measures—that this bill is not about how many people or the types of people that are coming to our country but how we treat people when they get here. We found it an issue of justice, fairness and equity. For those reasons we opposed most of the measures proposed by the government in relation to the two-year waiting period.

But of course, as we know, we received support for the ones before us now—carer's pension, widow allowance, et cetera. We acknowledge that the opposition supported the government on those benefits that had not been mentioned in the election campaign. We understand that rationale, but the Democrats still remain opposed to the two-year waiting period for those benefits as well.

BREAK.PARA: In this case we also need to make clear that the policy of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) did change. I think it was acknowledged by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in correspondence. It was very clear to me in the election campaign that the benefits that were being talked about in relation to a two‐year waiting period were those that already had a waiting period—specifically, sickness, the dole, youth training. It was acknowledged by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives on 22 May last year when he said:
Can I just make it perfectly clear to the Leader of the Opposition that . . . You introduced a six-month period. All we have done is to extend your six months to two years.

There is no mention about going from a zero waiting period to a two-year waiting period. It was under the ALP government that payments such as the sickness allowance, the parenting allowance, the youth training allowance and the dole had a six-month waiting period attached to them. In the election campaign the coalition said that they would extend the waiting period to two years, but they did not seek to extend that waiting period to about 12 other social security measures.

It is important to make clear not only to members of the parliament but also to members of the community who may be listening and who may have been under different impressions as a result of the media hype and propaganda which surrounded the last debate on this issue that the Senate gave the coalition three out of four social security waiting periods which they requested and which they campaigned on during the election. There is a two-year waiting period for youth training, sickness and unemployment benefits. Any attempts by commentators, shock jocks or any other media personalities to imply otherwise is quite false and quite wrong.

These are not trifling measures, but they cut to the heart of how we treat people in this country. They go to the very issue of what it is like to live in a free, civilised and democratic community. There are principal reasons why we have opposed these measures. There are also reasons in relation to the election campaign. Basically our objection has been on the grounds of fairness and a changed position by the government.

I would like to make clear the estimated cost of these measures. If the minister has a different estimation, I hope she will make it clear. I was concerned by the view perpetuated by the Treasurer, Peter Costello, that somehow these measures would cost an inordinate amount. His figures have been quite large. My understanding is that the estimated cost of not applying the waiting period to those benefits that previously did not have a waiting period is between $28 million and $50 million per annum. If the minister could clarify that, I would appreciate it. The Treasurer has implied that there would be a budget blow‐out as a consequence of these measures. These measures are unfair and inequitable. For those reasons, the Democrats's position has not changed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly indicate to the committee that I will be supporting this motion. I suspect that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) will clarify her intentions in regard to certain measures before they are debated, particularly amendments 10 to 14.

SPEECH.PARA: I have looked at the issue of the mandate which the government is talking about. Whether or not the government has a mandate, this chamber has the right to review legislation and to consider those matters on their merits. However, members of this chamber need to understand that when confronted with legislation which is clearly of a fiscal character, in order to achieve the government's and therefore the country's fiscal targets, this also needs to be considered.

In that context, we have had considerable discussions. In fact, before the legislation was originally proposed, certain discussions took place. Those discussions resulted in a number of amendments ab initio, including, for example, the question of widows allowance. It was proposed by the government that widows allowance not be available within the two-year period. What if a married couple came to Australia and the husband was killed the next day? Obviously there is a need for the government to take those matters into consideration. It did that ab initio and, because of changed circumstances, such people will receive widows allowance.

After the original legislation was passed, we in this chamber expressed support for a number of other areas. I would like to give an example. It is one which you know of, Mr Chairman, because it is about a constituent of yours in Queensland whom I understand you had a good deal to do with. A pensioner on a single pension married a person in Europe who did not have residency status in Australia. He then brought his bride out here. Under these provisions, he would go from a single pension to a half married pension and she would not get any pension. Because he married, he will go from a single pension to a half married pension—which is much less—and his spouse will be excluded.

That was picked up by the minister after representation was made to her. A number of things have happened like that, and I will not go into them. But I do indicate to the Senate that I will be supporting the motion that has been moved.
I have looked thoroughly at this question of what was said by the minister at the time. In a press release on 23 May 1996, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, stated:
Migrants entering Australia after 1 April 1996 will now have to have wait two years for some welfare benefits instead of six months, as is currently the case.
She then went on to state:
A coalition government will continue to grant all refugee and humanitarian migrants eligibility to access welfare benefits immediately upon their arrival in Australia.

Access to welfare benefits for migrants, other than refugee and humanitarian migrants, will be available after two years under a coalition government. This extension will have little direct impact on those migrants, particularly those in the preferential family reunion category, who are accepted for entry into Australia on the basis of formal assurances of support.
I will read the next paragraph to foreshadow what I will do on another matter:
Full access to family allowance and Medicare will be maintained for all migrants immediately upon arrival.

Thus on the family allowance I will be taking a different view from that which I am taking on this, because that clearly indicates they are talking about not just family payments but also full access to family allowance. But I am anticipating another debate.

I do not know whether the minister wants to explain to the Senate at the present moment what she is proposing on the disability matters and also the carer pensions. In addition, I have had discussions with the minister in respect of special benefits. As I understand it, the government has prepared guidelines which will cover a number of the cases which clearly call for a consideration under the special benefits guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, has said that he will be supporting the motion that has been moved, indicating therefore, that he will be supporting the government in that we do not insist on the amendments that the Senate made to the legislation on its first passage through this place. I just draw that to the honourable senator's attention. He may make that clear for my benefit. This would mean that the Senate's insistence that there is not a two-year waiting period for newly arrived migrants for these benefits be dropped.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens have not changed our position on this at all. What the Senate is now considering is whether it will stand firm on its refusal to allow the government to cut benefits to newly arrived residents to this country meaning that they could not access those benefits for two years. If the cutting of those benefits does occur, it will put a whole range of people coming into the country at a disadvantage with other citizens. It will make them second class citizens from the outset. It will make life much more difficult for them, even though a good many of those people who are to arrive will be sheltered from these provisions.

We opposed that measure before and will be opposing it again. Senator Stott Despoja has pointed out that these pretty niggardly measures from the government will save it something less than $50 million in a given year. The minister wrinkles her brow at that and she obviously will give us the correct figures in a moment—and that will be no difficulty for her.

But, whatever the figure is, I would point out again that this government buckled at the knees over the diesel fuel rebate and this year will be handing the mining giants, those corporations, in this country $800 million on a platter. So the government cannot extend these benefits to newly arrived Australians because it wants to save somewhere between $29 million and $50 million, but it can find $800 million to give to the big mining corporations who happen to enter the same dinner cycle that many members of the government are in. BHP alone will get $100 million benefit out of having its fuel levy returned to it in a big fat cheque at the end of the year—and that is more than double the amount that would allow thousands of people coming to this country to have access to benefits when they need them.

Senator Harradine has given two instances where people will find themselves seriously disadvantaged and in real trouble in this country if they do not have the same access to benefits that the rest of Australians do. But, of course, there are myriad such examples of hardship this government is foisting on newly arrived Australians because it wants to tighten its budget in a way that it seems totally unable to do and incapable of doing when it comes to its friends in the big mining corporations. I only to have remind the Senate that we are talking about corporations which in some cases have two, three or four executives each taking home more than $1 million each year.

What we see is this divisiveness, through government policy, of the community in a way which makes it difficult for those people who are least advantaged, and feathers the nests and lines the pockets of those who are already advantaged. That is what this government is about. It is pretty nasty and it is pretty mean. The chamber said that we are not going to have that at least as far as these provisions are concerned, because the numbers were here to keep some compassion and commonsense and regard for newly arrived Australians who would otherwise not have access to these benefits, at least in the period six months to two years after they arrived here.

I would hope that the chamber is going to stand firm on this. I would hope that the argument that prevailed before will prevail now. I would hope that Senator Harradine—when he said he would be supporting the motion that the chamber does not insist on its previous amendments—maybe got that back-to-front. Otherwise it means that the chamber will potentially lose the numbers to stick by the principle and the social justice and the real need for specific peoples in our community that this chamber stood for just a couple of months ago.

I hope we are not going to get into the situation we had just before Christmas, where Senator Harradine cut out, like filleting a fish, some sections of the community to get social security benefits because he used that pivotal vote when others could not. They got cut out because they happened to have a different lifestyle or a different configuration in the way in which they live. That remains to be seen.

I reiterate that the Greens are opposed to the government's contention that this chamber should buckle to the government majority in the House of Representatives and drop the interest of the people who will be hurt. This is real hurt we are talking about. They will be deprived of benefits that other Australians have access to because they happened to have newly arrived in this country. I would hope that other members of the chamber will stand firm on those amendments that the senators made in majority to the government's legislation before Christmas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on some of the issues that have been raised by honourable senators. I would first of all insist that, despite earlier claims of Senator Stott Despoja, the government sincerely believes it has a mandate. As I said in the debate that we had for nearly an hour last night, the government took a document to the Australian people. It states:

BREAK.PARA: Access to welfare benefits for migrants other than refugee and humanitarian migrants will be available after two years under a Coalition Government.

That is spelled out in the document Meeting our commitments , which was released by Mr Costello in February last year during the election. So Australians were told very clearly what we would do. The document went on:

Full access to Family Allowance and Medicare will be maintained for all migrants immediately upon arrival. As well, the Coalition will provide a `safety net' in the form of a special allowance for those migrants whose circumstances change significantly after arrival in Australia for reasons beyond their personal control.

We also said that the financial implications would be something in the order of $616 million over three years. That, quite clearly, was never going to be just an extension of the existing measures relating to some unemployment payments that the previous government already had in place for the first six months of a migrant's arrival. Clearly, just by the amount of savings that were being described there, it was welfare benefits, not social security benefits, that were spelled out here. Clearly that can cover welfare benefits in other portfolios such as health and family services or DEETYA.

So there has been no attempt to hoodwink the Australian people and certainly no attempt to hoodwink this chamber. I believe the statement of our intention—and therefore the claim for our mandate—has been always very clear. Despite the debate that went on in this chamber, the government stands by its claim to a mandate.

We did not believe that six months was sufficient. Senator Brown, in his comments just now, portrayed us as mean-spirited, hard-hearted and all the other things that he said. I would remind him that in international terms Australia is one of the most generous countries for access by new people to benefits, to protection, to a safety net. There will still be a safety net there for people in those first two years if their circumstances change.

I would also remind the chamber that migrants are expected to either sponsor themselves or be sponsored by others. It is not the duty of the Australian taxpayer to be first cab off the rank in rushing to support a newcomer to our country. It is first of all the duty of the migrant themselves, if they have self‐sponsored, or of the person who sponsored them. That is where the first call for support should come and, after that, the taxpayer.

Senator Stott Despoja and again Senator Brown had a bit to say about costs and savings. It seems to me that they cannot have been in question time last year when I answered this question. I have a feeling the question might have come from Senator Kernot, but the response which I gave to the chamber that time was similar to the following.

It was estimated that the savings from a two-year waiting period for newly arrived migrants would be $546 million over four years and, with the chamber's amendments, those savings would be reduced by approximately $400 million. The key reasons for this reduction in savings are not applying a 104-week waiting period for a range of payments and concessions, and that is $214.7 million over four years; delaying the starting date of the 104‐week waiting period for the newstart, youth training and sickness allowance; not applying a 104‐week waiting period for partners, and that was $124.9 million over four years; and not applying a 104‐week waiting period for special benefit where the circumstances had not changed unexpectedly, and that was another $65.3 million over four years. The chamber should also note that these figures are in 1996-97 dollars and have not been out‐turned.

When the figures are adjusted for future year dollars, the cost of the Senate amendments is even higher—approximately $427 million over the four years. I would like to very briefly go through some of the issues which have been raised, mainly by Senator Harradine. We have given a commitment that we will later move amendments which will enable special needs relatives to be exempt from the waiting period for the carer pension. That is because they are coming in on a visa which allows them to come in as the carer for somebody already in Australia. That is not only a humanitarian gesture but it is also of good sense to Australia, in that if there is somebody who can care for a family member, it is better for all concerned in financial terms as well.

I turn to the newly arrived residents waiting period for the disability wage supplement. Once again, we believe we have an electoral mandate. It should be clear that those who suffer disability after arrival in Australia, which causes a continuing inability to work, will be exempt. If that happens after they come here, for reasons beyond their control, they are exempt from that waiting period. I would also point out that the disability wage supplement is a substitute for the disability support pension, which has a 10-year resident waiting period. When you look at the pension situation, we have 10-year waiting periods and five-year waiting periods for pensions. It seems extraordinary that people can come on to a multiplicity of allowances. The chamber seems to think there should be no waiting period at all for many of them.

We have given an undertaking about our willingness to amend the guidelines which are used by delegates in the Department of Social Security in cases where an Australian resident marries and their spouse comes into this country and then, for a variety of reasons, such as unemployment or sickness, et cetera, they need assistance. The delegates in the Department of Social Security already have the discretion to determine that somebody who is on a pension at a single rate and marries will still be able to get a single rate, as happens already. If their partner is in hospital or in a nursing home, we would be prepared—and will—to amend the guidelines for the delegates so that it would include a spouse whose circumstances need support from their Australian resident spouse. So the Australian resident spouse would continue to receive a single rate of pension rather than the half married rate. I think that will help some people's concerns there.

Things such as the mature age allowance should always have been included in the six-month waiting period that the previous government introduced. It is, after all, an unemployment payment for older, long-term unemployed people. It should be treated along the same lines as the newstart allowance. It seems strange to me that it was not included at the time that the other unemployment payments had a waiting period imposed upon them. It is a basic income support payment for unemployed people and the community expects a waiting period to apply in those circumstances.

The question of special benefit has been raised by Senator Harradine, and it is one matter that I want to make quite clear. If the chamber's previously expressed will on this matter were to succeed under this debate now, we would have a wonderful loophole for anybody who was refused access under the legislation to any of the other payments being able to come around the back door and immediately apply for a special benefit. I cannot remember the exact figure but I think about 30 per cent would be expected to go via that route to obtain special benefits if the arrangements which the government wanted to put into place could not succeed.

It is important that there is an adequate safety net. There are two safety nets for migrants coming to Australia. There is the safety net of the undertaking which they themselves have given, perhaps as business migrants, or the undertaking which their sponsor has given by way of sponsorship or assurance of support. There is a safety net there that their needs will be met, and we expect that commitment to be honoured.

There is also proposed under the legislation a special benefit payment which will come into effect where circumstances have changed for a migrant after they arrived in this coun try. These changes include such things as becoming widowed, losing a pre-arranged job after they get here and domestic violence. A number of issues may occur to a migrant after they get here which they would not have been able to prevent.

The special benefit payment is there and it is fair. It is not only fair to the migrant, it is also fair to the Australian taxpayer. We do not expect people to come to Australia thinking that they are automatically going to get immediate help from the Australian taxpayer. It is only in special circumstances when that should happen. Partner allowance, of course, is once again part of the unemployment benefits system in the sense that the former government took an approach that people should qualify for social security payments in their own right. It is appropriate that, if unemployment payments are not going to be available, neither should the partner allowance.

The parenting allowance already has a 26‐week waiting period. That rebate will still be available through the taxation system for newly arrived migrants who are in the work force. The larger proportion of parenting allowance, which is $244.10 a fortnight, forms the main part of the previous payment for spouses of the unemployed. People who experience a change in their circumstances after arriving in Australia and, therefore, qualify for special benefit would still have access to healthcare cards. TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak in the adjournment debate about the government's proposed work for the dole scheme. Following the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), I have listened now for two days to what he deems is a very worthwhile program that is somehow going to deliver to some 100,000 young unemployed Australians the opportunity to gain full and meaningful work. In announcing this proposal, he said that some 30,000 of these young Australians have been out of work for periods of longer than six months and that the government would introduce a number of pilot programs of both a compulsory and voluntary nature. He also went on to say that there would need to be an amendment to the Social Security Act to enable the program to be implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of these issues raise some very serious questions, given the now government's criticism of our labour market programs when we were in government, which had far greater coverage and provided far greater opportunity for a significantly larger number of unemployed Australians, both young and old, to actually gain experience through properly accredited training programs. I think those programs had a very high success rate in that over the period 1994 to 1996 they actually provided for some 700,000 jobs.

I think one of the questions that the Prime Minister and the government have yet to address themselves to is: how is this scheme going to work? We can look at some of the statements the Prime Minister made in parliament. On 10 February 1997, in answer to a question from Mr Anthony, he says:

BREAK.PARA: We intend to pilot about 20 to 30 of these schemes in areas of high youth unemployment especially, but not only, in regional and rural areas of Australia.
He says further:

I believe that most Australians will strongly support the notion that it is not unfair in modern Australia to ask people, if they are able to do so, to undertake some work in return for the dole they receive.
He says further:

There is a hard core of about 30,000 young people who have been out of work for more than six months and they do comprise a particular social challenge to the entire Australian community. The emphasis in the work for the dole approach will be on community cooperation—cooperation between community groups and local business organisations in rural and regional areas of Australia.
He says further:
We are quite deliberately providing as many incentives and as much encouragement as possible for small business in Australia.

I want to look at the last point he made. So much for the incentives such as the removal of the bounties—the ship bounties, book bounties and computer bounties. That really has done a lot for small business by providing an incentive to employ people.

I am curious about this point he makes about the cooperation of communities and small businesses, et cetera. I would have thought that in any region of Australia there has been a concerted effort on the part of all Australians to try to do something about youth unemployment. I think the Prime Minister and the government have to answer some questions. How is this going to work in terms of administration and accepting responsibility? The Prime Minister says we will have to amend the Social Security Act. How do you amend the Social Security Act for only part of the population who receive a benefit?

It would be very interesting to know how you are going to amend an act—if you are going to have a pilot program that is going to involve some 5,000 beneficiaries of the dole—in a way that it only goes to a certain number of people who receive a similar benefit. Surely that is discrimination at best. I would be very interested to hear the government explain how they are going to do that.

With regard to young people, it has been reported in the media that there is an expected cost—in addition to the money that they receive for the dole, for which they will work up to 20 hours a week depending on their age—of around $3,000 for each person. I am not sure for what period of time that will actually apply and for how long these young people will be expected to continue to work for the dole.

At what point in time will they be able to achieve full-time work? Moreover, what effect will that have on full-time opportunities? Why wouldn't it be the case that businesses and/or even local government may choose to exploit a set of circumstances where people are required to work compulsorily for the dole when there are no jobs? In many regions of Australia there are no jobs. If there were jobs, people would be getting them now.

You cannot wave a magic wand and create jobs, particularly in some rural areas of this country, because of the very nature of the changes to the rural sector. We have seen the development of larger land holdings, and technology and plant and equipment has seen a significant decline in the number of job opportunities that come from farming. That then flows into the small rural centres where, simply because of the loss of wages revenue, there is decline in the number of jobs in service areas such as shops and other services that are provided within that community and other communities within Australia.

I think the government has some significant explaining to do as to how this will be the panacea, along with the green corps, which will only apply to a small number of people. It is focused on environmental repair and enhancement of the environment of this country. I am not quite sure what real benefit that will be in delivering training to people who seek to work in the areas of, say, information technology. Whilst there was some criticism of the schemes that we had in place, they were delivering. I will be very interested in whether or not this announcement was a major recommendation from the unemployment task force that the Prime Minister set up a while ago or whether or not they even knew about it.

A whole host of other questions that I would like answered relate to how it is proposed to deal with workers' compensation, the supervision costs of these people and the issue of safety equipment and transport. They will still only get the dole. They will do 15 to 20 hours work, depending on their age. They will be confronted with additional costs, I would imagine, in transporting themselves, privately or publicly, to the employment that they will be required to do. What compensation will be made to them in those circumstances?

I agree that there probably is some community sentiment about this notion of work for the dole and the unemployed making some contribution. At the end of the day, given the criticism that the government made of our programs when it was in opposition, surely they have a responsibility—they claim that this is going to provide what we could not—to come into the parliament and explain how this program, announced by the Prime Minister, is going to work, how it will create opportunities for young people to get full-time jobs. I am quite sure they cannot.

There are so many questions I want to ask but, unfortunately, I do not have the time to go to them. I am sure that over the coming days we will pursue them and make sure that this government has not used this announcement to shield itself from some other pressing issues that still remain unanswered. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to talk about the devastating floods in the north of South Australia and the effect that they are having not only on pastoral families but on the livestock that they farm in that area. The torrential rains that have fallen over the last week or so have been the heaviest in a decade. In fact, over the last 10 days they have received the equivalent of three or four years worth of rain. Almost half of the state's north has been affected. It is quite heartbreaking to learn that more rain is expected to come within the next couple of days.

BREAK.PARA: I drove through that area just a couple of weeks ago, up towards Broken Hill and through the areas particularly affected. At that time they were looking like they always do at this time of the year—dry and dusty and, of course, very hot. Rain is always welcome in the pastoral countries but not of this quantity and not in this short period of time. The normally dry and quite dusty pastoral areas are seas of very muddy, turgid water. As some of us already know, the stock losses have been quite significant and the rain has damaged roads and the railway.

The defence forces and the emergency services are standing by. Today they made food drops to some of the properties in the area that are particularly isolated and are likely to be without food for the next week or so. At this stage it is very difficult to assess the property damage in the area because there is still a great deal of water about, but it is likely to be between $60,000 and $100,000 per property. That is pretty devastating when one considers the difficulties that livestock farmers have been having with the wool prices and cattle prices as they are. With rain still falling and so much of the livestock roaming free in that area, at this stage it is very difficult to know what those final total figures might be.

The railway line has been cut. I guess it is a bit of an irony that a couple of us were up in that area just 10 days ago looking at the future of the railway system, including the Indian Pacific line. We now have a situation where one of the trains is sitting up there and is likely to be there for several weeks yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's Australia.

—Yes, Senator Collins—the unpredictability of the elements in this country. However, I understand that the passengers have enjoyed something of an unusual trip and have now been safely delivered to Adelaide. In fact, 20 roads have been cut in the area. The Birdsville and Oodnadatta tracks have been cut and 120 metres of the sealed road itself, as well as the bridges, have been washed out.

BREAK.PARA: It may mean that tourists will not have access to this area until after Easter, which is another blow for an area which is just begin ning to develop a tourist industry. Many families are stuck in their homes but, of course, in this area that is nothing new. They are accustomed to a life of some adversity, and to be isolated is not unusual for them. In fact, I think many people who go to live up there prefer to stay there than come to the cities. I guess some of us can understand that.

My understanding is that 55,000 livestock have been affected. But, as I say, it is difficult to know the final number at this stage. Yesterday, the Westpac helicopter took nine tourists from near Anna Creek, where further flooding threatens. There are 16 locals who have taken refuge in Anna Creek Homestead. I guess they expect to stay there to sit out the flood.

Perhaps the best example of the character that comes out in rural people with this sort of adversity can be seen at the William Creek pub, which is 1,000 kilometres north of Adelaide. It is currently accessible only by helicopter. Some of us may have heard the publican speaking on the radio yesterday. He said, `We're ankle‐deep in water. We've got stranded tourists and residents in here. We're a bit short on food. For a pub to run out of food is quite acceptable, but for a pub to run out of beer is definitely not on.' He says there is no danger of that.

A number of tourists who were in the area have found themselves painting the inside of the pub to pass the time away. As we know, pastoralists always look for the silver lining and, I guess, so does the local publican. He said, `We'll make do with what we've got, basically. It's bad at the moment but, in time, with water being in the lake and the wildflowers and so on, there'll be a plus side. We'll come out of it okay. That's the best way of looking at it. We'll try not to worry about the problems, but look to the future.' I think that is the sort of attitude that binds rural Australia. It is an attitude that comes out with adversity, whether it is floods, fire or difficulties with commodity prices. Somehow they always try to look to the future. I am pleased to see Senator Bob Collins agrees with me there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thankfully, nobody has been seriously injured or affected in any personal way by the floods. Cars have been washed away and so on, which is always a difficulty in these sorts of areas where eight inches of rain has fallen in just two days.

BREAK.PARA: I think it is interesting to note that one of the more remote pastoralists said, `Well, it's a good thing the floods have come now and didn't happen in July. In the winter months our stock food is lower and we might lose more sheep.' A couple of the stations that are without electricity happily reported that they had barbecues by torchlight. I wonder if we in the city have quite that same sense of humour when our power goes off and we have difficulties with what we take for granted being just down the road and around the corner.

Many of the businesses that have been affected and which rely on tourism are optimistic that in due course charter flights will be taken up there to look at the wildflowers, the pelicans and all those other things that miraculously appear in the outback after rain. All I can say, and I am sure I speak on behalf of many of us, is that we hope there will not be too much more rain. We were pleased to hear Premier Olsen offering his support at this time when the floods are the worst in South Australia for a decade. Our thoughts will be with those people as they begin to put their lives back together.

TALK.START.PARA: —All governments of all political persuasions make good and bad decisions. At the end of the day, of course, you hope that the good decisions outnumber the bad ones. One of the bad decisions of the former Fraser government—in my view, one of the worst decisions—was to build this parliament house. It is not that I mind so much the $1½ billion that was spent on this non‐functional polis; it is the fact that $1½ billion was spent on building a structure when the architects had forgotten the primary purpose for which the building was designed—that is, a parliament.

BREAK.PARA: It is a great public monument—I concede that. It has got some very nice works of art in it that I like very much. It has got great big wide‐open public spaces that many people love to come and visit. But it is a non‐functional building as far as the parliament is concerned. Of course, everyone who works in it knows that; we knew that from day one. We found out very early when we moved in here that the acoustics of these billion dollar chambers were appalling. The debating chambers of a parliament, in my view, should be the focus of the architecture of a parliament. Everything should be built around the chambers. This, after all, is where the maximum amount of public attention is spent. But these chambers have got appalling acoustics. We found out shortly after we moved in. We had to spend a fortune. In fact, I was on the committee that determined to change all the electronics in here on which the sound depends.

These chambers have no natural acoustics. They are awful. As I have said before, debating in here is like debating Darth Vader. It is all electronically controlled. You actually have to wait for about half a second before they can plug you in. You cannot get within striking distance of the enemy, which is what you should be able to do in a chamber built on the parliamentary system. Of course, you could do all that in the old parliament.

What should have happened is that we should have restored Old Parliament House. We should have built an annex immediately behind it in the same successful way as they have done in Queensland. The state parliament of Queensland has one of the most magnificent pieces of restored built heritage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Beautiful.

—Absolutely beautiful. Senator Herron, you are right. It has a modern annex out the back. It has all of the history and beauty and tradition—and I am a traditionalist; I freely concede it—of an old Westminster parliament house, but it has provided the necessary office space at a fraction of the cost that this monstrosity has cost the Australian taxpayers.

BREAK.PARA: These chambers have got all of the atmosphere of a public toilet. If these chambers remain here for 50 years they will never ever have any more atmosphere than a public toilet. That is not going to change with the years. This Parliament House was a billion dollar folly. I regret every working day of my life as a parliamentarian that we are here. I regret it so much that I have stopped going down to the old house, because on my first visit down there, after a year in here, when I went into those beautiful old chambers I was reminded of the intimacy of those chambers—how small they were in real terms.

What nonsense that you have to fit every single member of parliament into the chambers necessarily. The House of Commons does not have any problem with that and neither should we. What should have happened? We should have kept all of the history, all of the tradition, all of the beauty, all of the debating capacity of those old chambers, built an annex out the back and had decent office accommodation—and that would have happened at a fraction of the cost of this. This was a major error in my view, with the greatest respect to the Fraser government.

Having said that though, we should not add insult to injury. When we left Old Parliament House there were some loopy suggestions—and loopy they were—that we would tear off its foundations that magnificent Speaker's chair, which is modelled on the House of Commons Speaker's chair, in the old House of Representatives chamber where it is currently an adornment and carry it up the hill and put it in this art deco modern monstrosity where it would look frightful. I just thought it was the usual sort of loopy conservatism you get occasionally that makes no sense. But to my horror I found out tonight on the news that this is being seriously suggested again and that some idiot has actually spent $12,000 of hard‐earned taxpayers' money to have a consultant look at the possibility of doing it at a cost of $500,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I ask this madman, whoever he is, to cease and desist. Stop now! It is not the money I mind so much. We have already spent $1½ billion on this monstrosity, so half a million dollars to wreck the history of the original chamber in the House of Representatives I suppose is a flea bite compared to that. I did not realise they were serious. But the Speaker was on TV tonight saying, `Oh, yes. We have a consultant examining all this.' It is not the half a million dollars I mind; it is adding insult to injury.

BREAK.PARA: It is perfectly true that the Speaker's chair in the new Parliament House is not a thing of beauty and a joy forever. What that means is that it is completely in accord with the rest of the chamber. It is true that I have always personally thought that it looks like the backside of a departing tram—and it does—but that again makes it completely in accord with the unlovely chamber that it sits in. That beautiful piece of Gothic architecture—and I am sure that is probably wrong in technical terms; that lovely piece of architecture—the original Speaker's chair in the original chamber of the House of Representatives, would look totally incongruous in the modern chamber of the House of Representatives.

Three crimes would be committed at once at huge cost to the taxpayer. First of all, the historical significance of the Speaker's chair in the context of the chamber where it was placed and used would be destroyed utterly and at the same time insult the eye constantly by being completely incongruous in the modern setting in which it would be placed at a total cost to the taxpayer of half a million dollars.

I have to say that we all know there is a great big streak of truth in Yes, Minister. That is where it gets its humour from, exaggerated of course in real terms, but this would be a piece of folly that not even Yes, Minister contemplated and, I think, this would be folly against the built heritage of Australia. It would make this monstrosity even worse than it is now. But what is a worse crime is that it would sully the appearance and the historical importance of the original chamber of the House of Representatives which, with great respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, in my view is where we should still be debating this issue. So I call upon whichever fool is in fact pursuing this folly to cease and desist.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Australia Council's Literature Fund has recently cut program funding to Australia's oldest literary magazine, Meanjin , by approximately 44 per cent.

(3) Is the Minister aware that this funding cut, in conjunction with Victorian Government plans to also cut funding to Meanjin , threatens the continued existence of Meanjin .

(4) In recognition of the significant contribution Meanjin has made, and continues to make, to the arts in Australia, will the Minister intervene to seek a reconsideration of the decision of the Literature Fund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have been informed by the Australia Council of the recent decision made by the Literature Fund to reduce its grant to Meanjin to $20,000 for the calendar year 1997, as compared to $36,000 in 1996.
(2) The selection criteria used by the Literature Fund in assessing the applications received from magazines under the Program Grant category are as follows:

PARA.TAB: evidence that the program of activities is high quality, well planned and viable;
effective management of finances and administration including a well developed forward plan which features strategies for increasing self sustainability;
evidence of effective promotion and distribution capabilities;
appropriate payment to writers; and
national literary and cultural significance of the proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) I am aware of claims to that effect. The Australia Council has advised that:

PARA.TAB: the Literature Fund is not Meanjin 's sole source of funding and, therefore, the cut by the Literature Fund alone should not threaten its continued existence;

the major source of its financial resources should be the income it receives from subscriptions to the magazine.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (5) The standards established by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) for rescue and fire fighting services remain unchanged and airport operators will continue to be required to meet these standards.

sulted. This matter was an agenda item at the Rescue and Fire Fighting Service Consultative Council meeting on 25 October 1996.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to an incident which occurred on 2 October 1996 regarding two pairs of A4 Skyhawks from HMAS Albatross observed flying at low altitude in the Morton National Park along the Clyde River Gorge:
(1) Were Royal Australian Navy and New Zealand Defence Forces responsible for this incident.
(2) How often do exercises of this nature occur.
(3) What is the rationale behind conducting exercises of this nature in national parks.

(4) (a) Has the department conducted any research on the impact of these flights on wildlife; and (b) has the department investigated the impact of very high sound pressure associated with low level flights of jet aircraft, the impact of exhaust gases and their accumulation, and the impact on humans and wildlife; if not, why not.

(5) Is there any arrangement between the department and the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales with regard to the use of the Budawang Wilderness Area for these exercises; if so, what are the terms of the agreement.

(6) Would the Government consider initiating discussions with the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales in order that a suitable `Fly Neighbourly' policy be devel oped for the Nowra region—to preclude flights through and over national parks and designated wilderness areas, such as those in place over Kakadu National Park and the Great Barrier Reef; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The aircraft involved were Royal New Zealand Air Force No 2 Squadron A4 Skyhawks which are based at HMAS Albatross under the terms of the Australian/New Zealand Enhanced Nowra Agreement. This Agreement is in place for both countries to benefit from Maritime Strike and Maritime Air Defence training. The Agreement also allows for No 2 Squadron to conduct essential pilot training in the HMAS Albatross air training areas.

(2) No 2 Squadron A4 Skyhawks only operate in the air training areas above the National Park for very short periods, on an irregular basis, depending on training requirements. The average use of the training areas by
No 2 Squadron is a total of one hour per month.

(3) These exercises are conducted in the military controlled airspace above the National Park. In this case, it is designated Danger Area 423, which has been in use for 30 years. There is no specific policy for the use of airspace above wilderness areas for low flying. While some sensitive areas, such as Kakadu, have individual agreements in place to restrict and control low flying, there is no such agreement for any part of the Morton National Park. The nature of this training requires that operations take place in mountainous terrain, and remote from urban and populated areas. Every effort is made to minimise the impact of flying on all environments. Furthermore, this activity is purposely conducted well away from populated areas to lessen the impact of noise on the wider Shoalhaven community.
(4) (a) The department has not conducted research into the impacts of these flights on wildlife specifically in Morton National Park.

(b) While no specific investigation has been conducted on the impact of very high sound pressures (noise) from low level flights of jet aircraft in the Morton National Park, studies have been conducted at RAAF Base Amberley and RAAF Base Darwin. These studies have specifically looked at the impact of noise on humans in urban areas. The very low frequency and duration of these flights over the Morton National Park means the likelihood of exhaust gases accumulating in and affecting the Park is considered to be remote. This view is supported by the evidently pristine nature of the Park which has allowed the declaration of the wilderness area.

(5) There is no agreement between the Department and the National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) of New South Wales (NSW) with regard to the use of Budawang Wilderness Area. However, the NPWS of NSW was advised in 1995 of the Department's requirement for continued use of the airspace above the National Park, and have subsequently raised no objections or concerns.

(6) The Government will consider suitable arrangements which ensure the relative priorities of both Defence and environmental requirements. However, many military training areas are purposely located in remote areas, some being national parks, in order that the impact of such training causes minimal impact on urban communities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, without notice, on 12 December 1996 (Hansard page 7320):

QUESTION.PARA: Will taxpayers with non‐business wealth (such as an art collection) worth many millions of dollars be eligible for CGT rollover relief if their net business assets are less than $5 million?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will provide Capital Gains Tax (CGT) rollover relief to small and medium sized enterprises. To be eligible for rollover relief taxpayers must satisfy a number of tests, including that the net value of the taxpayer's assets must not exceed $5 million.

For the purposes of meeting this test, an `asset' does not include, where the taxpayer is an individual who is not acting as a trustee, an asset for the personal use and enjoyment of the individual or an associate of the individual. As a result, if an individual has an expensive antique or art collection which is kept for the individual's personal use and enjoyment, then it will not be taken into account in determining whether the $5 million threshold is satisfied. The taxpayer will not be eligible for rollover relief on disposal of items from the antique or art collection, as these items are not active assets in the taxpayer's business.

However, different rules apply if an individual is acting as a trustee. For example, where a trust owns both business assets and other assets (such as antiques or works of art), the value of all of the assets owned by the trust will be taken into account in determining whether the $5 million threshold is satisfied.
